input_text:
The French real estate market is experiencing a major downturn in 2023. Transaction volume dropped by 22% in the first half of 2023 compared to the same period in 2022, falling from 1.15 million to 897,000 annualized transactions. Mortgage interest rates climbed from 1.1% in January 2022 to 3.45% in September 2023, reducing household real estate purchasing power by 25%. The average price per square meter in Paris fell by 5.2% year-over-year, settling at 10,230 euros in the third quarter of 2023.

First-time buyers are the hardest hit: their share of real estate purchases dropped from 45% in 2021 to 31% in 2023. The mortgage application rejection rate reached 35%, compared to 15% in 2021. The High Council for Financial Stability (HCSF) maintains strict lending criteria: a maximum debt-to-income ratio of 35% and a maximum loan term of 25 years. Mortgage lending volume fell by 40% in the first half of 2023.

In the provinces, the situation is mixed. Mid-sized cities (Limoges, Saint-Etienne, Clermont-Ferrand) still show price increases of 3 to 7%, driven by the post-Covid remote work effect. Conversely, regional metropolises such as Lyon (-3.8%), Bordeaux (-4.1%), and Nantes (-5.6%) are experiencing significant corrections. The average time to sell increased from 64 days in 2022 to 89 days in 2023.
goal: Extract key facts about the French real estate market downturn

gold_facts.text: Real estate transaction volume in France dropped by 22% in the first half of 2023, falling from 1.15 million to 897,000 annualized transactions.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: Transaction volume dropped by 22% in the first half of 2023 compared to the same period in 2022, falling from 1.15 million to 897,000 annualized transactions

gold_facts.text: Mortgage interest rates climbed from 1.1% in January 2022 to 3.45% in September 2023, reducing real estate purchasing power by 25%.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: Mortgage interest rates climbed from 1.1% in January 2022 to 3.45% in September 2023, reducing household real estate purchasing power by 25%

gold_facts.text: The average price per square meter in Paris fell by 5.2% year-over-year, to 10,230 euros in the third quarter of 2023.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: The average price per square meter in Paris fell by 5.2% year-over-year, settling at 10,230 euros in the third quarter of 2023

gold_facts.text: The share of first-time buyers in real estate purchases dropped from 45% in 2021 to 31% in 2023.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: their share of real estate purchases dropped from 45% in 2021 to 31% in 2023

gold_facts.text: The mortgage application rejection rate reached 35%, compared to 15% in 2021, and lending volume fell by 40%.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: The mortgage application rejection rate reached 35%, compared to 15% in 2021

gold_facts.text: Mid-sized cities (Limoges, Saint-Etienne, Clermont-Ferrand) show price increases of 3 to 7%, driven by the remote work effect.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: Mid-sized cities (Limoges, Saint-Etienne, Clermont-Ferrand) still show price increases of 3 to 7%

gold_facts.text: Regional metropolises are experiencing corrections: Lyon (-3.8%), Bordeaux (-4.1%), and Nantes (-5.6%).
gold_facts.source_excerpt: regional metropolises such as Lyon (-3.8%), Bordeaux (-4.1%), and Nantes (-5.6%) are experiencing significant corrections

input_text:
The European pharmaceutical industry is facing a deep restructuring. Pharmaceutical R&D investments in Europe reached 41.5 billion euros in 2022, up 8.3% from 2021, but remain below the $72 billion invested in the United States. The number of clinical trials launched in Europe decreased by 14% between 2019 and 2022, falling from 4,200 to 3,612 trials per year, while the United States and China recorded increases of 7% and 23% respectively.

The European biosimilar market is growing rapidly: it reached 12.3 billion euros in 2022, a 28% increase from 2021. Biosimilars now account for 38% of the volume of biological medicines in Europe, compared to only 12% in the United States. The European Medicines Agency (EMA) approved 22 new biosimilars in 2022, bringing the total to 92 authorized biosimilars. The savings generated by biosimilars for European healthcare systems are estimated at 6.5 billion euros in 2022.

The shortage of essential medicines is worsening in Europe: 3,200 supply disruptions were reported in France in 2022, compared to 868 in 2018. Amoxicillin, paracetamol, and certain cancer drugs are among the most affected medicines. Europe's dependence on Asia for active pharmaceutical ingredients is critical: 80% of active pharmaceutical ingredients are manufactured in India and China, compared to 60% twenty years ago.
goal: Extract key facts about the restructuring of the European pharmaceutical industry

gold_facts.text: Pharmaceutical R&D investments in Europe reached 41.5 billion euros in 2022 (+8.3%), but remain below the $72 billion invested in the United States.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: Pharmaceutical R&D investments in Europe reached 41.5 billion euros in 2022, up 8.3% from 2021, but remain below the $72 billion invested in the United States

gold_facts.text: The number of clinical trials in Europe decreased by 14% between 2019 and 2022 (from 4,200 to 3,612), while the United States (+7%) and China (+23%) are growing.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: The number of clinical trials launched in Europe decreased by 14% between 2019 and 2022, falling from 4,200 to 3,612 trials per year

gold_facts.text: The European biosimilar market reached 12.3 billion euros in 2022 (+28%) and accounts for 38% of the volume of biological medicines in Europe.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: it reached 12.3 billion euros in 2022, a 28% increase from 2021. Biosimilars now account for 38% of the volume of biological medicines in Europe

gold_facts.text: The EMA approved 22 new biosimilars in 2022, bringing the total to 92, generating 6.5 billion euros in savings for European healthcare systems.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: The European Medicines Agency (EMA) approved 22 new biosimilars in 2022, bringing the total to 92 authorized biosimilars

gold_facts.text: 3,200 medicine supply disruptions were reported in France in 2022, compared to 868 in 2018.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: 3,200 supply disruptions were reported in France in 2022, compared to 868 in 2018

gold_facts.text: 80% of active pharmaceutical ingredients are manufactured in India and China, compared to 60% twenty years ago.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: 80% of active pharmaceutical ingredients are manufactured in India and China, compared to 60% twenty years ago

input_text:
The European venture capital market is going through a correction period after the euphoria of 2021. Venture capital investments in Europe totaled 52 billion euros in 2022, down 35% from the record 80 billion in 2021. The number of European unicorns (startups valued at over one billion euros) nevertheless reached 136 in 2023, compared to 98 in 2021. France ranks second in Europe with 28 unicorns, behind the United Kingdom (47) and ahead of Germany (31).

Startup valuations have undergone a major correction: the median valuation of Series B funding rounds dropped from 320 million euros in 2021 to 180 million in 2023, a 44% decline. Down rounds (valuation lower than the previous round) accounted for 18% of deals in 2023, compared to only 5% in 2021. The average time between two funding rounds increased from 16 to 24 months.

The most resilient sectors are deeptech (AI, quantum, biotechnologies), which captured 38% of investments in 2023 compared to 22% in 2021, and cleantech (energy transition, sustainable mobility), which attracted 14.8 billion euros in investments in Europe in 2022. Conversely, the fintech and e-commerce sectors saw their funding drop by 52% and 61% respectively in 2023.
goal: Extract key facts about the state of the European venture capital market

gold_facts.text: Venture capital investments in Europe totaled 52 billion euros in 2022, down 35% from the record 80 billion in 2021.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: Venture capital investments in Europe totaled 52 billion euros in 2022, down 35% from the record 80 billion in 2021

gold_facts.text: Europe has 136 unicorns in 2023: United Kingdom (47), France (28), Germany (31).
gold_facts.source_excerpt: The number of European unicorns (startups valued at over one billion euros) nevertheless reached 136 in 2023

gold_facts.text: The median Series B valuation dropped from 320 million euros in 2021 to 180 million in 2023, a 44% decline.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: the median valuation of Series B funding rounds dropped from 320 million euros in 2021 to 180 million in 2023, a 44% decline

gold_facts.text: Down rounds accounted for 18% of deals in 2023 compared to 5% in 2021, and the time between rounds increased from 16 to 24 months.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: Down rounds (valuation lower than the previous round) accounted for 18% of deals in 2023, compared to only 5% in 2021

gold_facts.text: Deeptech (AI, quantum, biotech) captured 38% of investments in 2023 compared to 22% in 2021.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: deeptech (AI, quantum, biotechnologies), which captured 38% of investments in 2023 compared to 22% in 2021

gold_facts.text: Cleantech attracted 14.8 billion euros in investments in Europe in 2022.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: cleantech (energy transition, sustainable mobility), which attracted 14.8 billion euros in investments in Europe in 2022

gold_facts.text: Fintech and e-commerce funding dropped by 52% and 61% respectively in 2023.
gold_facts.source_excerpt: the fintech and e-commerce sectors saw their funding drop by 52% and 61% respectively in 2023
